France's new 'unproductive wealth' tax reflects a limited adjustment
subhead: MPs approved on Friday a modification of the real estate wealth tax. Its base was broadened, but the tax rate was reduced by a third for the very wealthy. Its yield remains unclear.

byline: Le Monde with AP and AFP

title: Louvre heist: Man and woman charged, but jewels still missing
Brazil's right wing seeks to capitalize on the deadliest police raid in its history
subhead: The operation carried out Tuesday in Rio de Janeiro against the criminal group Comando Vermelho left more than 130 dead. President Lula's government announced measures to improve coordination between federal and state security forces.
byline: By Anne-Dominique Correa (Rio de Janeiro, correspondance)

title: Two French policemen charged for allegedly raping a woman in custody
subhead: The woman is 26, while the two accused officers are 23 and 35, according to a source close to the case. A video showing a sexual act was discovered on the mobile phone of one of the officers under investigation.

title: The Orient Express pulls up in Paris: An opulent journey into the 1920s
subhead: The legendary luxury train is making a stop at Paris's Musée des Arts Décoratifs until spring. As part of the major exhibition dedicated to the centenary of Art Deco, three life-size mock-ups of the new Orient Express, set to return to service soon, are on display.

title: Maho Bah-Villemagne, transgender boxer: 'Not many people are concerned that I was born female and can get punched by men'
subhead: One year after his first fight in the men's category, the athlete stepped back into the ring on Saturday in Marseille. He reflects on his journey and criticizes the persistent misconceptions about gender in the world of sports.

Water rises and land sinks in Vietnam's Mekong Delta
subhead: 'Our planet at +1.5°C' (5/6) The Mekong Delta and Ho Chi Minh City, home to a third of Vietnam's population, face rising seas and the toll of decades of resource overuse, leaving much of the delta at risk of submersion.
byline: By Brice Pedroletti (Ho Chi Minh City, Can Tho (Vietnam), special correspondent) and Adrienne Surprenant

title: Before the Louvre heist, security at European museums was already a major concern
subhead: France is not the only country to have experienced a 'heist of the century,' nor the only one to question the protection of artworks on public display.
byline: By Cécile Boutelet (Berlin (Germany) correspondent), Anne-Françoise Hivert (Malmö (Sweden) correspondent), Allan Kaval (Rome (Italy) correspondent), Isabelle Piquer (Madrid (Spain) correspondent) and Jean-Pierre Stroobants (Brussels, correspondent)

title: A dizzying dive into Bob Wilson's Long Island theater of objects
subhead: Famous for his groundbreaking shows, the American stage director, who died this summer at the age of 83, was also a great lover of art and design. A compulsive collector of chairs, which he created for his productions, he left behind thousands of works gathered throughout his life, spread between his Manhattan loft-studio, storage warehouses and the Water Mill art center, which he founded on Long Island.
